topics.title: LM18-75 vs TDA2050 Distortion Test
topics.description: Discussion of distortion test results and comparison with TDA2050.
topics.coverage_text:
we're going to take a look at today. But first of all, why do I like these chips so
much? Well, they're simple 5-pin T0220 type packages. They don't require a lot of
extra components to make a nice little amplifier. You know, there's no mute or
standby pins that require extra components. And you know, on some of the chips with
the mute and standby, you have to use Zener diodes that hold the voltage in a
certain range so the chip stays in play mode. Like the TDA7264 has that type of
arrangement. It's kind of annoying. But with these, there's no mute or standby pin to
worry about. They're designed to have very good audio quality, low distortion, no
stability issues. And with some of these chips, I've seen in the step response
tests, which we'll look at today, that some of them did oscillate. They were easier to
make oscillate. And, well, I still have to test the TDA2050, but the LM1875 had no
problems in that test. Like I said, I do have to test this TDA2050, and we'll
check that out today. You can set them up for single supply or dual supply operation.
In my experience, they're reliable. You know, my main listening amp has the TDA2050 in it,
and it's on constantly for 10 years straight, and no problems with it. I never turn it off.
So as long as you use a good layout and big enough heatsink, it'll be just fine. Now these are what I
call the 20 watt class amplifier ICs. I mean, you can squeak more power out of them. In one of my
videos with the LM1875, I was able to get 40 watts, actually a little over 40 watts out of it. But that
was running it at its maximum supply voltage, which I would normally not do. But still, yeah, you can get
25, 30 watts out of these things. Okay, so I have first off the LM1875 here on these little boards.

topics.title: TDA2050 Intermodulation Distortion Test
topics.description: Discussion of intermodulation distortion test results.
topics.coverage_text:
I talked about these kits before. Have a really nice, well laid out board. Nice ground layout here.
You got the ceramic caps, bypass caps for the power supply. We're pretty much right at the
pins of the chip. And they go right into the ground plane here. And yeah, these are just excellent boards.
And because the TDA2050 has the same pin out, I can use it on the same board. Though I will have to
change the Bougereau cell components because they require a different value. We'll take a look at that
as well. I'm going to start out doing a power test. I'll measure it at three different voltages. If you
want a more comprehensive power test results, well, a few years ago, I did a test of the LM1875. I tested
it at a bunch of different load resistances and supply voltages. But I'm just going to do three
different ones here to compare the two chips. As always, I have my signal source going into the
preamp so I can control the level. That goes into the amplifier here. Non-inductive 4 ohm load on the
output. And the power supply is hooked up. I have these reservoir capacitors. You know, they're connected

topics.title: Current Limiter Circuit Issues
topics.description: Discussion of issues with current limiter circuit in TDA2050 and its impact on amplifier design.
topics.coverage_text:
here close to the chip. And the power supply is set up. And we'll run a few power tests. I'm actually
going to start out at plus or minus 12 volts. So we'll dial that in. And what I'll do here, I'll take
one measurement on camera and then I'll do the rest off camera to save time. Okay, power measurement time.
So we can dial out the clipping there. Right about there. And I have to put more waveforms on the
screen to get an accurate measurement. See, it always stays the same. But if I don't have enough
waveforms, you get a different number here. You get a higher number. So you get the wrong information.
Okay. So we have 6.61 volts RMS squared divided by 4 ohms. So 10.9 watts. That's plus or minus 12 volts.
Okay, power test.
7.18 volts RMS.

topics.title: Conclusion and Comparison Summary
topics.description: Summary of key points and comparison between LM18-75 and TDA2050.
topics.coverage_text:
By that by 4 is 12.8. Actually, 12.9. The 1875 was doing 10.9. And this one is doing 12.9.
So it's delivering a little more power than the LM1875 at the same supply voltage. But I'll run through
some more supply voltages and take some more measurements here and see how it stacks up at the
end. Okay, so now I'm looking at a condition called rail sticking. That's when you send the amplifier into
clipping. And you'll notice that it wants to stay stuck to the rail a little bit. You can see a little
notch there on the top and bottom, especially on the bottom. See how it's sticking to the rail a little
bit. So I'm using a 10 kilohertz signal. So we can see that clearly. And with the LM1875, you can see that
there is a little bit of rail sticking. That's because the transistors don't want to come out of
saturation or well, at least clipping. What that can do is when you do clip, that can make the clipping
sound a little bit more harsh. So the less you see it, the better. And we are running at 4 ohm load,
so it's going to be harder for the amplifier not to do that with the lower impedance load.
Okay, let's check rail sticking. This is 10 kilohertz with the 4 ohm load TDA 2050.
Oh yeah, pretty bad. Look at that rail sticking. Much worse than the LM1875.
So I'll stop that so I can turn off the amplifier. So they might be optimizing the chip to give more
output. But whenever you do stuff like that, you might be giving up something like stability or,
you know, something like this rail sticking. And it's pretty bad here. And we have Snickers here.
I'm going to pass through here. I don't know where he's going. I think he's going to lay in the corner there.
Yeah, whatever. What you're going to do? Oh, grab the camera here. He's going to knock the camera over.
He's going out.
